awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Innovating and Experiencing Punishment
awd_abstract_narration:
This research examines the causes and effects of changing punishment and incarceration practices, with a particular focus on the deepening divide between harsh, high-security prisons and more humane, low-security prisons.  The research explores 1) when and how more punitive decisions in penal incarceration get made over less punitive ones, 2) how prisoners and staff experience the implementation of these decisions within different facilities, 3) whether and how penal consciousness differs across prison security levels, and 4) how punishment innovation develops through bottom-up, local-level decision-making.  By developing a greater understanding of the factors that contribute to punishment innovation in models of incarceration and the effects of these innovations on prisoners and prison staff, this work will advance sociolegal and criminological understanding of penal exceptionalism, local-level prison innovation, and the experience of punishment. Findings will facilitate continued interchange of ideas that inform current U.S. policies and practices and contribute to a growing interest among policymakers in alternative incarceration models. Broader impacts include the training and education of undergraduate students and building an increasingly international community of punishment scholars.

The research design extends U.S.-focused work to Denmark, a nation often touted as a model of humane and limited incarceration. Known in the U.S. primarily for its "open" prisons--facilities free of perimeter fences and at least partially integrated with non-prison communities--Denmark has a long but largely unacknowledged history of solitary confinement. This study takes the design and opening of Denmark's newest, high-tech, maximum-security prison with a dedicated isolation wing as a starting point for examining the causes and effects of the deepening divide between harsh and humane punishment. Providing a detailed, localized analysis of punishment innovation and experience, and employing methods that include examination of government documents, analysis of news coverage, and interviews with key prison managers, architects, policymakers, prisoners, and prison staff, the project traces the inception, implementation, and impact of a particular punishment innovation.

por.por_cntn:
The Danish prison system, like its Scandinavian neighbors, is widely accepted as among the most humane in the world. Indeed, most of Denmark’s prisons are “open” prisons—facilities without secure perimeter fences. In recent years, however, Denmark has built two new “closed” (high security) prisons. In our research, we aimed to identify and understand the causes and effects of the increasing Danish investment in closed prisons. To do this, we conducted an investigation of how the newest closed prisons in Denmark were designed and built, examining the administrative decisions within the Danish Prison and Probation Service, the architectural designs, and the local-level decisions about exactly where to site the prisons and how to operate them. Second, we sought to understand how punishment differs across open and closed prisons and the implications of the expansion of closed prison facilities for prisoners throughout the Danish prison system. To accomplish these goals, we conducted ten weeks of fieldwork in and around the Danish prison system. Data collection consisted of ethnographic fieldwork and in-depth, semi-structured interviews with prisoners and staff at two open and two closed prisons. Fieldwork also consisted of tours at ancillary prison sites, in-depth interviews with prison administrators at national headquarters and with related prison and policy experts. In total, we conducted face-to-face interviews with 142 participants (77 prisoners, 48 staff, and 17 experts).

Our findings reveal that Danish prisons are not necessarily any less restrictive, coercive, or punitive than prisons in any other social and geographic context. In Danish prisons, staff are continuously tasked with striking a balance between “hard” and “soft” policies and practices.

Interestingly, prisoners experience punitive elements of incarceration (and staff implement them) in both hard, obviously harsh punishment practices (such as the extensive use of solitary confinement) and softer practices consistent with principles of normalization (such as permitting cell phones and conjugal visits in prison). The persistence of these punitive elements reveals that Danish prisons are not as “exceptionally” humane as they may appear. A close examination of the lived experience in Danish prisons reveals that suffering is fundamental to incarceration, with or without an overlay of bare conditions, long sentences, and abusive guards. Still, prison staff and officials simultaneously reveal a commitment to internal operational goals of order and security and more externally-oriented goals of resocialization of prisoners through normalization. One key way in which these contradictory goals are accomplished is through a process we describe as “acceptance of error.” Where Danish prisons appear soft, humane, or relatively materially comfortable, this often also represents an acceptance of imperfect results, such as escapes or the pervasiveness of drug use—even when these imperfections undermine harder security goals. On the other hand, as the system increasingly seeks to prevent error (for example by designing escape-proof closed prisons), the system hardens and the ideal of normalization weakens.

Over the course of our research, the Danish prison system confronted significant organizational change within a broader political context characterized by changing global migration patterns and a domestic preoccupation with combatting “terror” through a prioritization of risk management. Our preliminary analyses reveal that, in Denmark, the externality of political mandates represents the encroachment of relatively uninformed views on the nature of prisons and punishment upon the discretion of those whose very job it is to be informed. In this context, educated and informed correctional officers within prison facilities resist the hardening of the system, based on their informed views about the individuals experiencing punishment.

Our research, which provides a nuanced picture of what has been lauded as the most humane style of punishment in the world, reveals important lessons about fundamental aspects of incarceration in general, and the pros and cons of “soft” incarceration in particular. Specifically, our research into Danish practices, policies, and lived experiences of incarceration provides an important reference point for politicians and practitioners, as bipartisan support for prison reform ushers in new ways of thinking about incarceration, and prison leaders from across the United States visit European prisons looking for alternative practice models. Concepts like the acceptance of error—an important mechanism for achieving balance between hard and soft aspects of incarceration—may be instructive as we seek to reduce the costs and impacts of mass incarceration. And understanding the role of broader sociopolitical context, and the potential for internal institutional actors to leverage empirical knowledge to resist politicized reforms, provides new analytic paradigms for reform.

Our research has also made important methodological contributions: developing a framework for conducting mixed-methods (interviews, focus groups, ethnographic observation, and document analysis) research into international practices of punishment and analyzing the influence of our “outsider” status on our access and data collection process. As more systems adopt Nordic principles and practices, we anticipate furthering this work by conducting evaluative research to assess correctional change and impact on prisoners, staff, and communities.
